item.title: Israel reinforces Gaza border as conflict rages on
item.description: The country deploys additional tanks and troops as it mulls whether to launch a ground operation.

item.title: Israel-Gaza: BBC reporters' reaction on the ground
item.description: Violence in Gaza and Israel shows no sign of abating amid rocket fire, air strikes and civil unrest.

item.title: Indian variant: Government concern at speed of growth
item.description: Local and regional restrictions to tackle the Indian variant cannot be ruled out, ministers say.

item.title: David Cameron: I was paid far more at Greensill than as PM
item.description: But the ex-prime minister insists he was not just motivated by money when he lobbied ministers.

item.title: Covid: Wales residents urged to hold off foreign holidays
item.description: People should only go abroad if "essential" for at least three more weeks, Welsh ministers say.

item.title: Covid: Â£13.5bn needed to help pupils catch up, report says
item.description: The Education Policy Institute also calls for a longer school day and summer activities.

item.title: Covid: Biden hails 'great day' as he sheds mask in Oval Office
item.description: The president removes his mask in the Oval Office as the new health guidance is announced.

item.title: Sir Alex Ferguson grateful for extra years
item.description: Sir Alex Ferguson says he is "grateful for the three years extra" he feels he has had after surviving a brain haemorrhage in 2018.

item.title: Howard Beckett: Labour suspends union official after Patel tweet
item.description: Howard Beckett had apologised for posting that Home Secretary Priti Patel "should be deported".

item.title: Friends reunion premiere date and celebrity guests announced
item.description: The much-anticipated special will see the original cast and celebrities reflect on the series.

item.title: Agoraphobic mum-to-be can be forced to hospital for birth, court rules
item.description: The 21-year-old has an "overwhelming" fear of going out and wanted a home birth, the court heard.

item.title: Mary Beard's 'retirement present' to fund students
item.description: Historian and TV presenter is paying for scholarships to widen access to classics beyond "posh" people.

item.title: The papers: Cameron's grilling and race to stop India variant
item.description: The former prime minister facing questions over the his lobbying features on several front pages.

item.title: Covid: The cloud gardener who has an 18th floor balcony oasis
item.description: Jason Williams turned to gardening to help with anxiety and depression during lockdown.

item.title: St Helens couple become foster parents to honour son's wish
item.description: Harrison Ledsham asked his parents to foster when his sister was dying and when he got cancer.

item.title: Russia picks team for film shot on International Space Station
item.description: An actress and director will blast off in October - but Tom Cruise also plans to visit the ISS.

item.title: Dragons' Den confirms youngest-ever Dragon
item.description: Entrepreneur and author Steven Bartlett, 28, is to join the BBC business investment show.

item.title: Chrissy Teigen sorry for bullying Courtney Stodden on Twitter
item.description: TV personality Courtney Stodden accepts her apology but questions its sincerity.

item.title: Richard Osman wins author of the year after hit debut novel
item.description: The TV star's debut novel The Thursday Murder Club sees him triumph at the British Book Awards.

item.title: Film studio sorry for dubbing Laverne Cox's voice with a man
item.description: Laverne Cox's character in Oscar-winning film Promising Young Woman was dubbed by a man in Italy.

item.title: The NHS Covid legacy - long waits and lives at risk
item.description: Nearly a third of hospitals sees long waits balloon, as NHS warned backlog will take years to tackle.

item.title: Eid: 'You can be Muslim and still enjoy playing football'
item.description: For young Muslim footballers like Omar and Rahma, it's vital that faith and football go together.

item.title: Queen's Speech debate: Waiting lists, social care and other claims fact-checked
item.description: Politicians debated the government's plans - set out in the Queen's Speech - and made a series of claims on subjects including hospital waiting lists and social care.

item.title: Uyghur imams targeted in China's Xinjiang crackdown
item.description: China has targeted Muslim religious leaders, according to a new report, charging many with extremism.

item.title: Lampedusa: Italy's gateway to Europe struggles with migrant influx
item.description: Italy appeals for EU help as 2,000 arrivals within days fill Lampedusa's migrant camp.

item.title: 'Cocaine of the sea' threatens critically endangered vaquita
item.description: The vaquita marina in Mexico is threatened by a clash of interests between fishing and conservation.

item.title: I love being a mogul: The Hollywood stars going into business
item.description: With the pandemic shutting down Hollywood over the past year, actors have been starting companies.

item.title: St Vincent: 'Without music, I'd be dead'
item.description: Inspired by her father's release from prison, St Vincent says her new album feels like a lifeline.

item.title: Tommy Mallet: 'I don't read emails longer than five words'
item.description: The Only Way Is Essex star Tommy Mallet opens up about the challenges he has faced with literacy and dyslexia.

item.title: Police expand use of overdose life-saver drug Naloxone
item.description: But officers' representatives are concerned the roles of police and paramedics are becoming blurred.

item.title: Israel-Gaza violence: The strength and limitations of Hamas' arsenal
item.description: The militant group possesses thousands of missiles of varying ranges that it can fire towards Israel.

item.title: Liverpool boost top-four hopes with win at Man Utd
item.description: Roberto Firmino scores twice as Liverpool boost their hopes of a finishing in the top four of the Premier League by beating Manchester United at Old Trafford.

item.title: Quadruple-chasing Chelsea best team I've ever been part of - Kerr
item.description: Australia international Sam Kerr says her Chelsea side is "definitely the best team I've ever been a part of".

item.title: Fans could travel to 14 August Joshua v Fury bout - Hearn
item.description: Saudi authorities hope to host overseas fans on if plans to stage Anthony Joshua v Tyson Fury on 14 August are finalised.

item.title: Hundreds of fans in anti-Glazer protest at Old Trafford
item.description: Hundreds of Manchester United fans protest against the club's owners while the team and Liverpool arrive at Old Trafford for a Premier League fixture.

item.title: Spendolini-Sirieix claims second European Championship medal with 10m bronze
item.description: Andrea Spendolini-Sirieix claims her second European Championship medal of the week with a brilliant bronze in the individual 10m final in Budapest.

item.title: Aston Villa 0-0 Everton: Drab stalemate dents visitors' European hopes
item.description: Everton's hopes of finishing in the European places suffer a blow as they play out a goalless Premier League draw at Aston Villa.

item.title: 'My biggest fear was losing my memory'
item.description: Sir Alex Ferguson and his son Jason talk to Dan Roan before the release of a new film about the former Manchester United manager.

item.title: Covid vaccine: Period changes could be a short-term side effect
item.description: Stories of genuine experiences shared online have been followed by a wave of anti-vaccine disinformation.

item.title: What are the India, Brazil, South Africa and UK variants?
item.description: Concern is growing over a rise in UK coronavirus cases linked to a variant from India.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: What is a Covid passport and what are the plans for the NHS app?
item.description: People travelling abroad from England will be able to use the NHS app to prove their Covid vaccination status.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 38 and 39 in England are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the rollout continues.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: Covid inquiry: What is it and how will it work?
item.description: An independent public inquiry has been announced, but how will it work?

item.title: Restaurants and pubs are reopening inside, but what are the rules?
item.description: People in England, Scotland and Wales will soon be able to drink inside a pub.

item.title: Covid: What are the social distancing rules and the rule of six?
item.description: Guidance on hugging close friends and family is being relaxed in England and Scotland from 17 May.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Lockdown restrictions will ease in England, Scotland and Wales from Monday 17 May.

item.title: Which countries are on the green list for foreign holidays?
item.description: Scotland is to adopt the same "traffic light" system for foreign travel as England.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Secondary school pupils in England will no longer be required to wear them in class from next week.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go.... and who with?
item.description: The rules on having a holiday in the UK have been relaxed - but restrictions remain.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the Covid-19 alert level system work?
item.description: The threat of Covid-19 in England is ranked through a five-level, colour-coded alert system.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as nearly 36 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: What refund rights are there for holidays abroad?
item.description: Quarantine-free overseas holidays will be possible after 17 May, but what rights do you have if plans or rules change?

item.title: 'Talk to me': A train driver asking men to open up
item.description: A tragedy inspired Scotland's only woman freight train driver to get men talking about mental health.

item.title: Chinese dreams on Native American land: A tale of cannabis boom and bust
item.description: How the pandemic cannabis boom led to chaos on the Navajo Nation, pitting two minorities against each other.

item.title: The 'smart and cheeky' Aboriginal boy teaching Australia a lesson
item.description: A film about an Aboriginal boy's experience of school shines a light on Australia's failure to give all children a fair start.

item.title: Joe Ligon: America's 'longest juvenile lifer' on 68 years in prison
item.description: After waiting seven decades for freedom, Joe Ligon tells the BBC how he intends to spend the rest of his days.

item.title: Lelush: How a sulky Russian model became China's slacker icon
item.description: Getting trapped in a boy band reality TV contest was just the start of Lelush's unlikely journey.
